question: Hepatitis B vaccination is given to a patient. His serum will reveal:
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., Anti HBs. Ag (Ref: Ananthanarayan, 9th/e, p. 548 and 8th/e, p. 543)* Anti HBs. Ag is protective antibody.* It is the only serological marker, present after immunization.
opc: IgM Anti - HBc. Ag and HBs. Ag
opd: IgM and IgG Anti - HBc. Ag

question: Hepatitis A virus is best diagnosed by:
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., IgM antibodies in serum (Ref: 19th/e, Harrison, 2004)"Detection of Ig. Mspecific anti -HAV in the blood of an acutely infected patient confirms the diagnosis of hepatitis A. " HAV is the only cultivable hepatitis virus. Diagnosis is based on IgM detection due to the early presence of these antibodies in patient serum, in fact so early that a lack of hepatitis A antibodies at the onset of clinical manifestations excludes hepatitis A.

question: Virus causing Latent infection (or Latent period is shown by which virus) -
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., HBV [Ref: Harrison 18th/ep. 1438: 17th/e p. 1084). Latent infection is caused byo HBVo HCVo Rabies Viruso Measles Viruso HIVo HTLVo HPVo HSVo VZVo Some pox viruseso EBVo CMVo HHV-6. HHV-7, HHV-8(Human Herpes Virus)

question: Serum marker after Hepatitis B vaccination -
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., Anti-HBs. Ag HBs. Ag. Anti HBs. Ag. HBe. Ag. Anti HBe. Ag. Anti HBe. Ag. Acute HBV (high infectivity)+-+ Ig. MAcute HBV (low infectivity)+- +Ig. MChronic HBV (high infectivity)+-+ Ig. GChronic HBV (low infectivity)+- +Ig. GRecovery-+-+Ig. GImmunized-+ -

question: The serological marker of acute Hepatitis B infection is -
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., HBs. Ag+Core antibody In acute hepatitis following serological markers are present: HBs. Ag. IgM anti HBc Ag (in recent infection) or IgG anti HBc Ag (in remote infection). HBe Ag (with high infectivity) or Anti HBe Ag (with low infectivity). HBs. Ag. Anti HBs Ag. HBe Ag. Anti HBe Ag. Anti HBc Ag. Acute HBV (high infecti vity)+ + Ig. MAcute HBV (low infecti vity)+ +Ig. MChronic HBV (high infectivity)+ + Ig. GChronic HBV (low infectivity)+ +Ig. GRecovery' + +Ig. GImmunized +

question: Reverse transcriptase is a RNA dependent DNA polymerase. Which of the following uses reverse transcriptase?
exp: Ans. b. Hepatitis B virus (Ref: Ananthanarayan 9/e p544, 8/e p540; Harrison 19/e p2005; Robbins 9/e p831-832). Hepatitis B virus uses reverse transcriptase. Hepatitis B virus: A polymerase (Pol) that exhibits both DNA polymerase activity and reverse transcriptase activity. Genomic replication occurs via an intermediate RNA template, through a unique replication cycle: DNA - RNA - DNA. "--Robbins 9/e p832"The third of the HBV genes is the largest, the Pgene, which codes for the DMA polymerase: as noted above, this enzyme has both DMA-dependent DMA polymerase and RMA-dependent reverse transcriptase activities. "--Harrison 19/e p2005. Hepatitis B virus Genes & Antigens. Gene. Antigen ProducedC gene. HBc. Ag (Hepatitis B core antigen)QC & Pre C genes. HBe. Ag (Hepatitis B e antigen) QS gene. HBs. Ag (Hepatitis B surface antigen): large, middle & small HBs. Ag QP gene. DNA polymerase (pol) & reverse transcriptase QX gene. HBx. Ag: virus replication & transcriptional transactivator Q

question: Carrier state does not exist for:
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e. Hepatitis A virus(Ref: Harrison, 18th/e, p. 2546; 19th/e, p. 2006). Carrier. Present. Absent. HBV HAV HCV HEV HDV (only with HBV ) Remember: Non A, Non B hepatitis is HCV.

question: Incubation period of HBV is:
exp: Ans. is 'a' i. e., 45 to 180 days (Ref: Harrison, 18th/e, p. 2546; 19th/e, p. 2006) Remember: Enterically transmitted non - A, non - B (NANB) virus - HEV. Parenterally transmitted NANB - HAV. Hepatitis Virus. Incubation period. HAV15 - 45 days (mean 30 days)HBV30 - 180 days. HCV15 - 160 days (mean 50 days)HDV30 - 180 days. HEV14 - 60 days (mean 40 days)

question: Recent hepatitis infection is best diagnosed by:
exp: Ans. is 'd' i. e., IgM anti HBc abs(Ref: Ananthanarayan, 9th/e, p. 548 and 8th/e, p. 544)* HBs. Ag is the first marker to be elevated and Anti HBc.- IgM appears within 1 - 2 weeks after the appearance of HBs. Ag and lasts for 3 - 6 months.* Diagnostic tests in recent hepatitis B infection are HBs. Ag detection and HBc.- IgM and overall best is to look out for IgM anti HBc.

question: A young pregnant woman presents with fulminant hepatic failure. The most likely aetiological agent is:
exp: Ans. is 'c' i. e., Hepatitis E virus(Ref: Ananthanarayan, 9th/e, 550 and 8th/e, p. 546)* Fulminant hepatitis may occur rarely in 1 - 2% of cases, except for the pregnant women who are particularly at higher risk (20%) of developing fulminant hepatitis.

question: A thirty-year-man presented with nausea, fever and jaundice of 5 days duration. The biochemical tests revealed a bilirubin of 6. 7 mg/dl (conjugated 5. 0 mg/dl) with SGOT /SGPT (AST/ALT) 1230/900 IU/ ml The serological tests showed presence of HBs. Ag, IgM anti HBc and HBe. Ag. The most likely diagnosis:
exp: Ans. is 'b' i. e., Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity (Ref: Ananthanarayan, 9th/e, p. 548 and 8th/e, p. 544)* Presence of HBs. Ag, IgM anti HBc and HBe. Ag suggest the diagnosis of acute hepatitis B with high infectivity. HBs. Ag. Anti HBs. Ag. HBe. Ag Anti HBe. Ag Anti HBc. Ag. Acute. HBV (high infectivity)+-+ Ig. MAcute HBV (low infectivity)+- +Ig. MChronic HBV (high infectivity)+-+ Ig. GChronic HBV (low infectivity)+- +Ig. GRecovery-+-+Ig. GImmunized-+ -
opa: Chronic hepatitis B infection with high infectivity
opb: Acute hepatitis B infection with high infectivity
opc: Chronic hepatitis B infection with low infectivity
opd: Acute hepatitis B infection with low infectivity
